awd_titl_txt: PFI-TT: Smart pose and position guidance system for construction workers' safety and productivity
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Partnerships for Innovation - Technology Translation (PFI-TT) project is to improve worker safety and productivity in dynamic construction job sites by enabling commercialization of a wireless pose and position guidance system. If successful, this project is expected to radically change job hazard safety management for the $1.2 trillion U.S. construction industry in which approximately three to four workers die every working day. The proposed technology is expected to help owners, contractors, and construction managers to make better and safer decisions for dynamic construction work. In addition, this study can provide valuable data regarding the safety condition of workers, which benefits the individuals' health as well as safety management and society in general. The collected data will preserve safety knowledge within the company and help knowledge transfer from experienced professionals to new generations. The research project will also provide an opportunity to engage underrepresented students from diverse socio-economic backgrounds to learn about the challenging engineering problems in the construction industry and equip them with scientific knowledge to address those problems.

The proposed project aims to provide a holistic solution for intelligently monitoring individual workers' exposure to hazards and unsafe postures. For a system to be feasible as well as practically acceptable in construction which has dynamic and transient work environmental characteristics, the system needs to satisfy many factors: cost, ease of use, scalability, real-time ability, network connectivity, form factor, system deployment, accuracy, reliability, and privacy. While satisfying the factors, a Building Information Model (BIM)-driven Internet of Things (IoT) application will be used as a central platform for user interface and sensor tracking algorithms in the proposed PFI project. In particular, when the construction work schedules are set and incorporated into BIM, daily and weekly work activity information is extracted. These data can serve to automatically or semi-automatically identify potential hazards in advance based on construction progress. In addition to the location-based safety risks, postural working conditions of the workers are monitored through a motion recognition function using machine learning algorithms. The monitored and quantified information can provide valuable data regarding the safety condition of workers, empower our knowledge about each worker's health and safety-related behavior in a quantitative manner, and thus deliver an objective, comprehensive safety reinforcing system to a job site.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
With expenditures totaling $1.2 trillion, the United States construction market, one of the largest globally, faces a persistent concern with high fatality rates. Out of 4,386 total worker fatalities reported in private industry sectors in 2014, about 900 occurred in construction, underscoring its significant impact. Due to the dynamic nature of construction, organizations must efficiently capture, store, and disseminate data to enhance safety measures. However, the industry has struggled with fragmented and inconsistent methods due to the inability to automatically collect on-site data.

General contractors and subcontractors overseeing jobsite safety in construction are potential customers of the proposed innovation, AwareSite. While some commercial safety products exist, they are often too costly for large construction sites and fail to adequately address various hazards. AwareSite, developed by our research team, offers scalability to be economically implemented on large-scale jobsites. It provides comprehensive hazard warnings and quantified safety indicators, enabling customers to mitigate injuries, fatalities, costs, and delays associated with accidents, ultimately reducing insurance premiums.

During the research period, the team developed a Personnel Protection Unit (PPU) hardware device and software algorithms to recognize workers’ motion, track their approximate location, and detect dangerous proximity situations. Integrating the hardware and software units, the team built a high-performance motion recognition framework that predicts labor productivity and improves the safety of construction workers. The framework integrated into AwareSite is innovative in scalability, real-time tracking and monitoring, and health safety management for individual workers. By using small, interconnected, cost-effective IoT devices, the system can be economically applied to various construction sizes. Additionally, it offers real-time monitoring of individual workers on-site and provides meaningful safety information through quantified safety metrics. Integrated with an interactive web interface, AwareSite can provide meaningful safety information, detect and warn users of hazardous proximity situations, and predict worker motions in a non-intrusive fashion. The generated safety information allows for automatic record-keeping and can be used for new safety strategic plan development or personal safety training and education strategies.

To identify patterns from temporal sequential data and detect specific motions, the team developed a motion recognition algorithm based on deep neural networks, specifically a two-stacked Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) network. Based on the finding that two motion sensors located at key body locations showed similar motion recognition accuracy as multiple distributed sensors, the team manufactured two types of PPUs and developed the motion recognition model accordingly. The developed LSTM network outperformed existing motion recognition methods and recognized more types of motions with higher accuracy using a smaller number of sensors than previous works. Construction field tests were conducted in three different jobsites, including a bridge construction site and two asphalt road paving sites. Construction workers carried the PPUs in their safety vests while performing their normal tasks. As a result, the developed LSTM networks for three jobsites showed accuracy levels of 97.6%, 95.93%, and 97.36%, respectively. These results validate the technical and practical feasibility of the developed motion recognition algorithm in real-world construction projects and confirm that the AwareSite system is non-intrusive and induces minimal impact on the workers involved.

The focus of advancing the proposed technology lies in creating an integrated solution to meet the diverse safety needs of construction contractors while intelligently monitoring individual workers' exposure to hazards and unsafe postures. Scaling up the technology presents an opportunity to effectively address unmet safety needs in the construction industry. The collected and quantified data can offer valuable insights into workers' safety conditions, enhancing our understanding of their safety-related behavior and facilitating the implementation of objective safety reinforcement measures on job sites. As there are currently no directly competing products, The research team is positioned to pioneer the introduction of this smart health and safety tracking and management platform in the construction market.

The research project involved undergraduate and graduate students in original research and design tasks, with extensive system testing throughout development. During development, students gained practical experience in hardware and software design. Field tests also engaged students to coordinate with safety managers and workers, conducting feedback interviews. This hands-on experience aimed to broaden students' understanding of multidisciplinary research and innovation, nurturing lead researchers capable of commercializing the technology through a startup venture. Additionally, the project developed a curriculum focusing on individual path trajectory and motion-based behavioral studies for construction safety management, offering diverse learners practical experiences to enhance safety awareness. This educational initiative facilitated a shift in safety management practices, providing targeted interventions and increasing workers' self-awareness to mitigate injuries and fatalities in high-risk workplaces, thereby enhancing industry performance and reputation.
